comments.commentBody: Karen, have you tried the paleo diet? I don't know if it works for everybody, but it sure worked for me, and for many others, some of whom have posted here. None of the exercise, calorie cutting, or hunger. Seems to me it's worth a shot.
If work was only 30 hours a week, we would time to exercise, cook, and clean the house. (Or if work included exercise...)

Given the hypervigilance required to maintain weight loss, is it worth distorting your life to stay thin?  It IS important to eat well, with plenty of vegetables and pasture-raised meats or clean fish.  It is important to exercise,  But I don't lose weight or keep ir off without 2-3 hours a day of aerobic and strength-training exercise, but then I don't have time for work or family.  Instead I spend the time caring for others and educating people.  Sure I may cut a couple of years off my life, but there are other pursuits that are more important:  social justice, spiritual depth, education, researching the conditions of my patients.  To invest so much time and energy on weight loss when there is a 95% chance it won't work- and I have tried many times.  I'd rather make the world better than make myself thin.

"Why, in the face of scientific and anecdotal evidence do people think that losing weight is still a healthy and admirable goal?"

Apparently, you haven't read the conclusive epidemiological evidence that obesity, (BMI >30), doubles one's risk of cardiovascular disease and cancer. Moreover, type 2 diabetes, a disease exclusive to obesity, is not only the primary cause of blindness, renal failure and amputations, but typically shortens one's lifespan by a decade or more. Obesity can further affect one's quality of life, increasing the risk of asthma, arthritis and other autoimmune diseases. The scam of the obesity crisis is that the obese are not made to pay the significantly higher medical costs they impose on the rest of us.

Most of my family have struggled with their weight all their lives. One Sister has been on a diet all of her life and lost a little then gained a lot more. In the past two years she finally has lost her weight and seems to be keeping it off. She has lots of energy, is never hungry and looks great. She is 61 but looks so much younger now. She changed her diet to a Raw Foods Vegan Diet. She eats a lot, big salads, dehydrates for breads and blends her dressings. She eats better now than she ever has. So there is HOPE.

I think this is typical of how complex industries evolve. The parallels are all true of the the first 40 years of the automotive industry. Cars failed so often that Rolls Royce included a tool box bolted to the running board of every car. Tires went flat so frequently that many cars had two spares (think hard drive). Transmissions were crude. hand cranks to start (think DOS). Windshield wipers would stop when you accelerate (think blue screen of death). water pumps failed frequently (think overheating). They were big, heavy and inefficient (remember 286). They stalled frequently (think reboot).

i could go on and on

I agree with you, it's not just about calories. Also chemicals added to extend shelf life and thus  preserved food versus pickling or fermentation or added cultures may be a factor as well in the surge of obesity.

Really good point. I don't understand why his research is being ignored. It seems to me that there are *a lot* of people with similar findings and personal experience who haven't been considered here. I think it's the backlash against Paleo/Primal/Grain Free and the discounting of it as anything other than a fad.

Taubes's WHY WE GET FAT is the one that did it for me.  I must say it's frustrating to have lost weight easily and kept it off with no trouble, and to see all the comments that say, "There is no easy way; constant vigilance is the only answer."  I hope that as more people discover Atkins' pretty damn easy way of keeping weight off, it will eventually tip the scales of public awareness.

Tara,

I appreciate that you are reading and responding to the posts on this blog. I have to ask, have you read Taubes "Good Calories, Bad Calories"?

Because you should. It is not an obscure book, it is relevant to your article, and I think he even writes for your paper occasionally. If you disagree with him, I would be very interested in understanding why...but at this stage in the discussion, can you just ignore him?

It seems like the answer should be simple. Lets stop making fat people miserable. Lets stop judging character on the basis of physical traits. Wouldn't this be easier than trying to change everyone's body-- to the extent that we ask that they make weight control their life's work?
Someone wrote that the problem in the US is that we don't judge obese people enough. I am pretty certain that you would beg to differ.

I think the most relevant change in the past 50 years has been the increase in dieting, leading to rebound weight gain that's mainly biological, not psychological. If you're someone who prides yourself on staying thin and think it's a character issue, try losing 15 pounds and then notice how your body fights to put it back on. Though in doing so, you may condemn yourself to a lifetime of yoyo weight loss and regain and end up weighing 100 pounds more than when you started.

When the contract is up I'll move my wireless phone to www.pagepluscellular.com no hassle and much cheaper, prepaid and no contract.

Just another typical trashy American company.. I dislike Verizon and will never have their service. Having said that, should AT&T do the same I rid myself of them as well.  The evil American enterprises at their finest..

I have already reversed my one-at-a-time payments to another utility in my area and have reverted to the practice of paying with a check through the mail.  I'm sure it costs the company much more to process, so I'm mystified why they do it.  I recently left my cable company to go with Verizon FiOS, and now I'm wondering, did I do a dumb thing?
Back to paper payments. It'll be a jobs program for data entry clerks.
And the paperwork will contain (it 18 pt font) the statement:  "We'll really and truly still respect you in the morning"

$2 / month is $48 over a 2 year contract.  So before this I could pay however I wanted, and now paying manually with a credit card will cost me an additional $48 over the life of the contract.  That's material to me.

This is the exact reason more and more people are going to the prepaid services like Net10/Tracfone, Straight Talk, etc., among others.  There are no hidden fees with them or "gotchas".  An administrative fee for handing paper is somewhat ok if it's only a few cents per customer - but charges for automated online systems, and especially so much for each person, is completely unreasonable.  $2 may not sound like much to some, but if they really wanted to stretch it and say it's to pay for the equipment and services needed to do this, then at most, 25-cents per customer would more than cover it when multiplied by hundreds of thousands of people per month (or more)  that would be charged the fee.  Boo to Verizon ... this will definitely make me do some research to consider other options when my contract is up soon.

This is insanity, and nothing more than a way for the company to make unwarranted money for providing absolutely nothing!! I was looking at alternate vendors before I read this today; now it's virtually certain that I'll make the change.
